title.narrative: PACEA (Projet pour Améliorer la Cohérence de l’Enseignement Agricole)

description.narrative: **Résultats : **Pour arriver à nos ambitions, les produits suivants vont contribuer à la concrétisation directe des résultats du projet: (i) les référentiels de métiers-compétences, de formation, d’évaluation et de certification des compétences sont élaborés et disponibilisés, (ii) le réseau des lieux d’apprentissage pratique et d’encadrement de stages est mis en place, (iii) les preuves scientifiques sont disponibles sur l'impact des activités des programmes OKP sur les capacités des étudiants, élèves et des agriculteurs, (vi) le partenariat entre le Bureau d’études et des curricula de la formation technique(BECFTP) et le consortium international, incluant les experts burundais est solide et durable, (v) les capacités en matière d'agriculture durable et de sécurité alimentaire sont renforcées et la question de genre et de groupes marginalisés est incluse dans les stratégies de notre projet.

participating-org.narrative: Bureau d'études et des curricula de la formation technique et professionnelle (MEFTP)
International Centre for development oriented Research in Agriculture

mailing-address.narrative: P.O. Box 29777, 2502 LT The Hague, The Netherlands

title.narrative: Atelier de formation des enseignants des Instituts Techniques Agricoles du Burundi (ITAB) sur le module Plan Intégré du Paysan (PIP)
Project photo
Narrative report

description.narrative: Reporting is an important management tool which is used to inform relevant government officials and other stakeholders about the results being achieved by individual projects and the programme as a whole. For project partners, it is compulsory to use the prescribed Orange Knowledge annual report format in order to report on project achievements. The annual report also provides valuable data on the financial situation of the project. Based on an analysis of the project performance in relation to the project output(s) and expected outcome(s), a revision of the project work plan may be suggested by the project partners. The consequences of a possible revision on the project work plan and budget must be made clear in the annual report. Nuffic monitors outputs and outcomes and not activities . Therefore, the main focus of the annual report must be on the achievement of the project’s output(s) and planned outcome(s). The information provided in the annual reports of the projects is used by Nuffic to monitor the progress of the project and to inform the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and other stakeholders about the output(s) and outcome(s) being achieved by individual projects and the Orange Knowledge programme as a whole. Please note that if project progress is in accordance with the original planning, reporting requirements are minimal. Only in case of deviations from the planning, more elaboration is demanded. In the grant award letter, the dates for submission of the annual reports are mentioned. In case of a three-year project, between 5-7 reports are obligatory. The first report (0) is a very short report which focuses on specific conditions and/or recommendations in the grant. There is no need to report on progress in achieving outputs and outcomes, which is done in the first annual report. As annex to the report 0, the consortium agreements between the partners should be submitted. The final report must reflect on the entire project period.

title.narrative: 14. Final report TMT+/TMT

description.narrative:
Final conclusions TMT+/TMT (in case of final report) Reflect on how the training has contributed to addressing the capacity needs as described by the requesting organisation in the proposal form. How effective and efficient has the TMT+ been in reaching the desired objectives? Please formulate lessons learned and recommendations for the post-project period.
+
In your email submitting the final report, the partners will enclose: - an inventory of equipment purchased - a document signed by the (Lead partner) Dutch consortium/provider and Lead partner consortium country A or requesting organisation on the transfer of ownership - a list with the names and email addresses of staff members who participated in staff training for their registration in the Holland Alumni Network database

comment.narrative: 5 cursus (curricula) diplômant/non-diplômant et formations courtes mis à jour/nouvellement développés - **R5 **: 3 modules PIP développés (ITAB, FABI, CEM) - **R6** : 2 cours de courte durée agriculture durable et socio-vulgarisation

title.narrative: A.O.1. Improved gender equality and gender awareness in the knowledge institution

description.narrative: please enclose stories of change or examples of best practices

actual.value: Raising of awareness about gender equality is specifically done with the introduction of and training on the PIP modules, in which gender is one of the aspects of attention. These trainings are planned for 2021.

title.narrative: A.E.3. Number of staff that have gained qualitative and relevant knowledge and skills to develop and offer the revised/developed study programmes

comment.narrative: **- R1** : Au moins 12 formateurs de BECFTP et 400 enseignant des ITABs ayant gagné des connaissances et des compétences pertinentes sur la pédagogie de l'enseignement pour les référentiels d’évaluation **- R2** : 10 superviseurs de la FABI et 60 coordinateurs des lieux de stage formés sur la pédagogie et didactique des stages **- R5** : 10 enseignants des CEM, 10 enseignants des ITABs et 10 enseignants de l’UB ayant gagné des connaissances et des compétences pertinentes pour développer et offrir des modules PIP - **R5** : 5 enseignants de FABI formés aux modules techniques du PIP **- R6** : 30 enseignants d'UB qui ont participé à des cours de courte durée, 4 membres du personnel académique de l'UB ont participé à un cours de courte durée sur les compétences matière d'éducation innovante

comment.narrative: R2: 60 stagiaires de la FABI font un apprentissage pratique
5.1.5. Vingt (20) étudiants des deux ITAB ont effectué leur stage au sein d'une colline PIP/PADANE (**XXIV R5**)

title.narrative: A.E.4. Number of graduates delivered

comment.narrative: 400 diplômés (homme/femme/minorité diplôme/ non diplôme) (directement\*) 30% de femmes 100 étudiants des CEMs, 200 étudiants des ITABs et 100 étudiants de l’UB sont formé sur le module PIP (directement\*) commentaire Laura: 'Cela n'entre pas entièrement dans le cadre de notre projet ; l'admission est du ressort des institutions. La question est de savoir si ce pourcentage est réaliste.'

SROL.1 Human Security: Reduced levels of violence and levels of fear experienced
SROL.1.1. Number of beneficiaries (f/m) who report a reduction in violent incidents in the area where they live
SROL.1.10. Number of national/local authorities supported in addressing root causes and triggers of violent extremism, particularly through SRoL (push factors)
SROL.1.2. Number of beneficiaries (f/m) who report they are feeling secure in the area where they live
SROL.1.3. Number of beneficiaries (f/m) who report increased levels of trust in security sector actors
SROL.1.4. Number of beneficiaries who report having received positive service provision by formal and informal authorities with regard to human security
SROL.1.5. Number of beneficiaries (f/m) who report that they have a more negative perception about violent extremist organisations
SROL.1.6. Number of beneficiaries (f/m) from marginalised groups who report on reduced levels of violence and fear experienced
SROL.1.7. Number of policy influencing initiatives aimed at long-term stabilisation

SROL.1.8. Number of beneficiaries with relevant knowledge and skills to support the formal security sector to strengthen reform processes that ensure increased accountability, transparency and gendersensitivity
SROL.1.9. Number of community-based security sector providers that have improved knowledge and skills to offer effective, accountable and responsive service to citizens and government
SROL.2 Rule of Law Strengthened: Citizens are better able to access their rights through fair, efficient, impartial, independent and accountable institutions
SROL.2.1. Number of beneficiaries (f/m) with access to justice [note: this is an official DGIS-indicator] (separate out: no. of women who present cases of sexual violence or domestic abuse)
SROL.2.2. Number of beneficiaries (f/m) who have improved awareness of their rights and/or of how to address justice problems (claim, defend, and or recover rights)
SROL.2.3. Number of beneficiaries (f/m) who access transitional justice mechanisms
SROL.2.4. Number of beneficiaries (f/m) who have improved awareness of their rights
SROL.2.5. Number of beneficiaries (f/m) from marginalised groups who have improved access to their rights and judicial service facilities.
SROL.2.6. Number of beneficiaries with increased capacity to support policies that promote increase to access to justice

SROL.2.7. Number of beneficiaries with increased capacity to provide (policy) advice on specialised topics such as informal justice, commercial justice, rehabilitation, juvenile justice, sharia, gender issues
SROL.2.8. Number of justice innovations (e.g. scenario planning)
SROL.3 Peace processes & political governance: States, regional and local authorities and societies at large are able to effectively prevent and resolve conflict in a non-violent and inclusive manner
SROL.3.1. Number conflicts that are addressed and resolved by community structures by the programme (note: this is an ARC indicator)
SROL.3.2. Number of beneficiaries (f/m) who feel that community grievances of targeted groups (e.g. women, youth or a specific ethnic group) are effectively addressed (note: this is an ARC indicator)
SROL.3.3. Participation (and satisfaction) in governance processes (political decision-making, mediation and dialogue) by representation of various groups, with special reference to women and youth
SROL.3.4. Perception on accountability/transparency of governance structures
SROL.3.5. Number of beneficiaries (f/m) who feel represented by the government structures
SROL.3.6. Number of national and/or local level conflict resolution and peacebuilding mechanisms supported
SROL.3.7. Number of beneficiaries with increased knowledge and skills to support policy influencing of incountry and regional conflict resolution and peacebuilding interventions

SROL.3.8. Number of beneficiaries with increased knowledge and skills to support interventions at national level to increase civil society engagement and at local level to increase community engagement in political decision-making
SROL.3.9. Number of beneficiaries with improved capacity for policy influencing on aspects of political governance and state building
SROL.4 Social and economic reconstruction: Income generating and livelihoods opportunities to prevent the (re)occurrence of conflicts, instability or irregular migration
SROL.4.1. Number of beneficiaries (f/m) who feel represented by the government structures
SROL.4.10. Number of people supported to improve their income/ livelihood opportunities
SROL.4.2. (disaggregated) Number of programme beneficiaries who started a business / self-employment activity and sustained it 6 months after they started

SROL.4.3. (disaggregated) Number of programme beneficiaries who indicate that their business / self-employment activities (which existed already before the grantees' interventions) have grown over the last 6 months
SROL.4.4. (disaggregated) Number of trained/supported programme beneficiaries who have become employed
SROL.4.5. (disaggregated) Number of direct jobs supported by targeted companies
SROL.4.6. (disaggregated) Number of communities in programme areas that have adopted and are implementing livelihood protection strategies
SROL.4.7. Number of people with improved income in fragile and conflict-affected states
SROL.4.8. Number of people using new or improved water points in fragile and conflict-affected states
SROL.4.9. Number of direct jobs supported
